designations.source: A review of the status of the beetles of Great Britain: The stag beetles, dor beetles, dung beetles, chafers and their allies - Lucanidae, Geotrupidae, Trogidae and Scarabaeidae
designations.source_description: This report was commissioned to update the national threat status of beetles within the Lucanidae, Geotrupidae, Trogidae and Scarabaeidae. It covers all species in these groups, identifying those that are rare and/or under threat as well as non-threatened and nonnative species. Reviews for other invertebrate groups will follow.
designations.reporting_category: Red listing based on 2001 IUCN guidelines
designations.designation_description: Taxa which are neither threatened nor near threatened.
designations.comments: There is a danger of over-estimating the regional rarity of this species. Hectad counts are of only 14 hectads for the pre-1990 period and 10 for the 2000-2015 period, but this is a localised northern and western species and the Midland/north England counties of Derbyshire, North Cheshire and Staffordshire are, like Scotland, relatively poorly recorded for this genus, Also, woodland dung beetles like fasciatus are generally less easy to locate than those which frequent open sites like pasture. Consequently, it is afforded Amber status only. Future targeted surveys for the species in the south Penines district would be desirable as would searches in previous occupied central Midland sites. A lack of grazing in woodland may be a contributory factor to any decline, should one be operating.
